      <title>What if Trump’s audited while president?</title>
      <link>http://www.politico.com/tipsheets/morning-tax/2016/05/what-if-trumps-audited-while-president-the-irs-is-really-going-to-stop-calling-wyden-to-take-on-derivatives-214255</link>
      <description>The IRS is really going to stop calling — Wyden to take on derivatives</description>
      <content:encoded><p><b>IT’S A TRUMP DAY: </b>By now, you’ve probably heard how Donald Trump, the presumptive GOP nominee, said he is likely to break with four decades of precedent and not release his tax returns before November’s election. </p><p>Trump <a href="http://politi.co/1T6ePxm" target="_blank">claimed</a> voters wouldn’t learn much from his returns anyway. Mitt Romney <a href="http://politi.co/24Nd6RG" target="_blank">disagreed</a>. And to come full circle, Trump said later Wednesday that he still <a href="http://politi.co/1TR3hgk" target="_blank">hopes</a> to release his returns before November. </p><p>Joe Thorndike of Tax Analysts, a historian on these matters, <a href="http://cnnmon.ie/1Nr1UFZ" target="_blank">recounted</a> to CNN how former President Richard Nixon released his tax returns in 1973 while under audit, undercutting Trump’s claim that he needs to wait for the IRS to finish with its examination. (That’s actually where Nixon’s “I’m not a crook” line came from.) Also: Trump did release his returns under audit before, to Pennsylvania and New Jersey <a href="http://cnn.it/1Ojt01Z" target="_blank">gambling officials</a>. Finally, Justin Wolfers from The New York Times <a href="http://nyti.ms/1Nr9aBM" target="_blank">explains</a> what could be gleaned from Trump’s returns: “If you don’t release your returns, voters will infer that they’re not the very best tax returns.” </p><p><b>LET’S PUSH THIS FORWARD: </b>Let’s assume we’re dealing with a President Trump in the coming years, and his tax returns are once again under audit. Would there be any conflict there, given that Trump would be head of an executive branch that includes the Treasury Department and the IRS?</p><p>In a word: no. Both Thorndike and Dean Zerbe, a former top Senate Finance aide, told Morning Tax that the IRS already has a firewall in place to make sure there aren’t issues if any president is audited. “Whoever’s at the White House would basically cut the telephone cord between the White House and the IRS,” said Zerbe, now at alliantgroup.</p><p>On top of that, both Thorndike and Zerbe said there’s every reason to believe that lots of presidents have already been audited. (In fact, the Internal Revenue Manual says both the president's and vice president’s returns should be subject to “mandatory examinations.”) “There are quite a lot of audits that go on quite regularly on high-ranking officials,” Thorndike said.</p><p>Final thought: Hillary Clinton, the Democratic front-runner, and her husband would also seem to be at heightened risk for an audit, given how wealthy they are. (The same would’ve gone for Dick Cheney, John Kerry and other recent potential or actual presidents or vice presidents.)</p><p><b>IT’S THURSDAY, </b>and also the 236th anniversary of the Continental Army’s surrender of Charleston, S.C., to the British during the American Revolution. (Imagine how different the Charleston food scene might have been if we didn’t get it back.)</p><p>Give us your tips, feedback and favorite shrimp and grits spots. Email: <a href="mailto:bbecker@politico.com" target="_blank">bbecker@politico.com</a>, <a href="mailto:teckert@politico.com" target="_blank">teckert@politico.com</a>, <a href="mailto:bfaler@politico.com" target="_blank">bfaler@politico.com</a>, <a href="mailto:kodonnell@politico.com" target="_blank">kodonnell@politico.com</a>. Twitter: <a href="http://go.politicoemail.com/?qs=1c77d3ea556172898f68d06dafee6a945cb1488ac4897321d4c0b36f44f0d91e" target="_blank">@berniebecker3</a>, <a href="http://go.politicoemail.com/?qs=1c77d3ea55617289f3153904119a65fae9113525f8733048b20c9960938ccdc3" target="_blank">@tobyeckert</a>, <a href="http://go.politicoemail.com/?qs=1c77d3ea55617289d2cc26da08b1a1411f373e7cd55cf311933e3ed147298841" target="_blank">@brian_faler</a>, <a href="http://go.politicoemail.com/?qs=1c77d3ea5561728974c7b77223628a73099a7a9c8b168611d9cb6f0ba2cb75d8" target="_blank">@katyodonnell_ </a>, <a href="http://go.politicoemail.com/?qs=1c77d3ea55617289c533d3c6850dc148c0febd5d3d857c5497feca51ecae4617" target="_blank">@POLITICOPro</a> and <a href="http://go.politicoemail.com/?qs=1c77d3ea55617289b2f2eed9ee81f8696a82f3e2b3e8bfcc0691134797d205de" target="_blank">@Morning_Tax</a>.</p><p><b>CAN YOU BE TOO PREPPED FOR TAX REFORM? </b>Sen. Ron Wyden, the top Democrat on the Senate Finance Committee, is readying some more tax reform drafts for public consumption to potentially lay the groundwork for action next year, according to Bloomberg BNA. One area to expect some movement: Wyden’s looking at a proposal that would have some serious overlap with former House Ways and Means Chairman Dave Camp’s 2013 draft on derivatives and other financial products, but would also incorporate some of the responses to Camp’s draft, BNA reports. (Wyden’s recent draft on depreciation took some inspiration from former Senate Finance Chairman Max Baucus.) Also of note: Sen. Chuck Schumer, the next Democratic leader, said he hasn’t talked with House Speaker Paul Ryan about international tax reform, but has chatted with Ways and Means Chairman Kevin Brady. <a href="http://bit.ly/24Pw1id" target="_blank">http://bit.ly/24Pw1id</a></p><p><b>NO, FOR REAL — WE WON’T CALL YOU FIRST:</b> Remember how the IRS, in its efforts against identity theft, would repeatedly warn taxpayers that they wouldn’t make first contact over the phone to demand money? Well, apparently it was a bit of a different story when it came to audits. Tax Notes reports that people at a public taxpayer advocate forum last week complained that IRS employees called them to set up audits — which apparently confused the taxpayers because the IRS made such a big deal about not calling first. Now, the IRS — in what it calls “an abundance of caution” due to all the phone scams — said taxpayers will always be told by letter if they’ve been selected for an audit.</p><p>The agency said just a small percentage of first-audit contact came by phone for in-person field audits, and that “we have no indication that criminals claiming to represent the IRS on the phone have said they were calling to set up an appointment for a meeting.” (H/T: Tax Notes’ Luca Gattoni-Celli.) Full story here: <a href="http://bit.ly/1T9aueQ" target="_blank">http://bit.ly/1T9aueQ</a>.</p><p><b>MORE IRS: </b>The agency sent out around $94 billion worth of returns, for about 29.2 million returns, by Feb. 12 this year, The Wall Street Journal reports. But next year, the IRS can’t send any refunds out until Feb. 15 because of a new law taking aim at tax fraud, and tax preparers and consumer advocates say that’s going to put the squeeze on low-income households. <a href="http://on.wsj.com/1Nr3U16" target="_blank">http://on.wsj.com/1Nr3U16</a></p><p><b>A CARRIED INTEREST UPDATE: </b>Robert Rubin and Larry Summers, both Treasury secretaries under former President Bill Clinton, told private equity executive David Rubenstein just how little they thought of the preferential treatment of carried interest during an interview in Las Vegas. Summers, according to Business Insider, gave Rubenstein “backhanded praise” for lobbying to keep the tax break. “Rarely has a policy existed so long with such weak arguments in its favor,” he said. “It's the First Amendment, the Second Amendment, and carried interest, right?&quot; (Rubenstein argued that both Rubin and Summers could have gotten rid of the preference as Treasury secretary. Rubin suggested that Congress had to act.) <a href="http://read.bi/1UUi6kJ" target="_blank">http://read.bi/1UUi6kJ</a></p><p><b>BACK TO TRUMP: </b>We decided to put a little space between our Trump coverage for the day. Our Brian Faler and Pro Budget Brief’s Matthew Nussbaum examined how Sam Clovis, a top economic adviser to Trump, said the presumptive GOP nominee could pull off a budget surplus of $7 trillion at the end of a decade. Clovis also said the Tax Foundation — which really likes dynamic scoring — didn’t dynamically score Trump’s tax plan. Brian and Matt called Clovis’ remarks “a sometimes bewildering explanation of Trump's agenda.” Or to put it more deadpan: “Clovis' estimates are implausible, and are likely to raise questions about the advice the presumptive Republican presidential nominee is getting on the economy.” <a href="https://www.politicopro.com/tax/story/2016/05/top-trump-aide-says-plans-will-generate-up-to-7-trillion-budget-surplus-112752" target="_blank">http://politico.pro/1WqVnyv</a></p><p>POLITICO's Shane Goldmacher also has a follow-up on just what sort of changes Larry Kudlow and Stephen Moore want to make to Trump’s tax plan to reduce the revenue loss to $3.8 trillion — and it seems to go beyond mere tweaks, as Kudlow originally said. Alan Cole of the Tax Foundation said the plan would also cap itemized deductions, increase all the tax rates from Trump’s original plan and dramatically reduce the number of people who wouldn’t owe income taxes. <a href="https://www.politicopro.com/tax/story/2016/05/economists-revising-trump-tax-plan-would-make-more-people-pay-taxes-112636" target="_blank">http://politico.pro/24NfJ63</a></p><p><b>PACK YOUR PARKA: </b>The House Ways and Means tax policy subcommittee is bringing back an old favorite today — a member day inviting lawmakers to get about three minutes to discuss their legislation to improve the tax code. A bipartisan group of around three dozen House members have signed up to present in the always chilly Ways and Means hearing room.</p><p><b>MARK YOUR CALENDARS: </b>Senate Finance Chairman Orrin Hatch is holding a hearing on corporate integration on Tuesday, with witnesses like Michael Graetz from Columbia’s law school and Steve Rosenthal of the Urban-Brookings Tax Policy Center. Hatch has been working on a measure to effectively end the double taxation of corporate income for a while but has said he’s been delayed by the Joint Committee on Taxation. <a href="https://www.politicopro.com/tax/whiteboard/2016/05/hatch-announces-hearing-on-corporate-integration-071747" target="_blank">http://politico.pro/1qet4Vg</a></p><p><a href="http://bit.ly/233Jltc" target="_blank"><b>POLITICO Event - Morning Money</b></a><b>:</b> POLITICO's Ben White takes Morning Money live for a lunch briefing with President and CEO of the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta Dennis Lockhart and President and CEO of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco John C. Williams. <i>Tuesday, May 17 — Doors at 12:00 p.m.; The W Hotel — 515 15th St. NW.</i> <i><b>RSVP: <a href="http://bit.ly/233Jltc" target="_blank">http://bit.ly/233Jltc</a></b></i></p><p><b>INTERNATIONAL UPDATE</b> — </p><p><b>YOUR DAILY PANAMA PAPERS UPDATE: </b>The European Parliament has pushed back a decision over whether to investigate the allegations stemming from the leak of the Mossack Fonseca papers, POLITICO Europe’s Tara Palmeri reports. Top lawmakers had been expected to approve an inquiry today, but the presidents of the assembly’s political groups delayed after hearing from legal advisers. <a href="http://politi.co/1X31YgM" target="_blank">http://politi.co/1X31YgM</a> </p><p><b>SOMETHING’S MISSING: British </b>Prime Minister David Cameron, hosting an anti-corruption conference in London today, is expected to lay out how Britain plans to tamp down tax havens, The Wall Street Journal reports. At the same time, Panama and the British Virgin Islands, two of the more prominent tax havens in the world, won’t be there. (Secretary of State John Kerry will.) The U.K.’s transparency efforts include boosting information sharing among British dependencies, known to be hotbeds of offshore banking activity. <a href="http://on.wsj.com/1TQWJyp" target="_blank">http://on.wsj.com/1TQWJyp</a></p><p><b>RUSSIA FALLS SHORT: </b>The Panama Papers — and the over 6,000 Russian companies and people named in the trove — show that Russian President Vladimir Putin’s efforts to crack down on offshoring is falling short, The Associated Press reports. <a href="http://apne.ws/1sf2Q78" target="_blank">http://apne.ws/1sf2Q78</a></p><p><b>A NEW NAME: Australian </b>Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull was a director of an offshore company incorporated by Mossack Fonseca, according to The Sydney Morning Herald. A spokesman said Turnbull, a former investment banker who’s called for July 2 elections, didn’t know about the Mossack Fonseca link. <a href="http://bit.ly/1qeMidv" target="_blank">http://bit.ly/1qeMidv</a></p><p><b>STATE NEWS</b> — </p><p><b>THE CASE FOR THE ESTATE TAX: </b>The left-leaning Center on Budget and Policy Priorities makes the case for more states to install an estate tax, calling it key to reducing income inequality. Only 18 states and Washington, D.C., levy an estate tax, hitting 2.56 percent of estates in those places. “Estate tax revenue supports services that make a state an attractive place to do business and live,” CBPP’s Elizabeth McNichol writes. “Research confirms that very few wealthy individuals move as a result of an estate tax.” Opponents of the estate tax — who you’d certainly have to say have the momentum — do in fact argue that the estate tax hurts economic growth. CBPP paper: <a href="http://bit.ly/1TQUL0P" target="_blank">http://bit.ly/1TQUL0P</a></p><p><b>QUICK LINKS</b></p><p>— How long are the Panama Papers’ tentacles? Well, they reach Hermione (Emma Watson), of course. <a href="http://abcn.ws/1TbDY8P" target="_blank">http://abcn.ws/1TbDY8P</a></p><p>— Federal judge finds that Texas billionaires committed tax fraud. <a href="http://bit.ly/1WrdALD" target="_blank">http://bit.ly/1WrdALD</a></p><p>— IMF: About $2 trillion a year lost to public-sector bribes, siphoning away key revenues. <a href="http://reut.rs/1WqXJgF" target="_blank">http://reut.rs/1WqXJgF</a></p><p>— India will tax investments from Mauritius for first time in more than three decades. <a href="http://reut.rs/1VTT6v3" target="_blank">http://reut.rs/1VTT6v3</a></p><p><b>DID YOU KNOW?</b> A recent study suggests that the dodo bird, which went extinct on Mauritius more than 300 years ago, was more intelligent than its long-standing reputation (“dumb as a dodo bird”). <a href="http://reut.rs/1UUsI38" target="_blank">http://reut.rs/1UUsI38</a></p><br></content:encoded>

      <title>Priebus: It's up to Trump on whether to release his tax returns</title>
      <link>http://www.politico.com/story/2016/05/reince-priebus-donald-trump-tax-returns-223133</link>
      <description/>
      <content:encoded><p>Donald Trump can make his own decision about whether to release his tax returns before the general election, Republican National Committee Chairman Reince Priebus said Thursday.</p><p>The presumptive Republican presidential nominee on Wednesday <a href="http://www.politico.com/story/2016/05/donald-trump-tax-returns-223101" target="_blank">disputed</a> a quote attributed to him in an <a href="http://www.politico.com/story/2016/05/trump-no-release-tax-returns-223049" target="_blank">Associated Press report</a>, in which the billionaire reportedly suggested that he wouldn’t release his tax returns before November. The real estate mogul told Fox News host Greta Van Susteren that while he’s under audit “every single year,” he will “hopefully” release his tax returns before Nov. 8.</p><p>A February statement from the Internal Revenue Service, however, says there is nothing that prevents individuals from sharing their own tax information. As for whether Trump does or not, Priebus — who huddled with Trump and House Speaker Paul Ryan earlier on Thursday — told <a href="http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/rnc-chair-reince-priebus-donald-trump-presidential/story?id=39069383" target="_blank">ABC News</a> that it's up to him.</p><p>“I don’t know the rules on audits and I’m not going to get into that,&quot; Priebus said. “Every candidate can make their own decision.”</p><p>Priebus also indicated that the billionaire will tone down his rhetoric in the general election after a bitter primary that saw the political outsider best 16 Republican rivals.</p><p>“I think Donald Trump gets it completely about being presidential and gracious, and I can tell you that’s how he acts toward me in private,” Priebus said. “I think he understands that getting to that place is important. But you know Donald Trump also has to be Donald Trump. I mean, that’s what got him there.”</p><br></content:encoded>

      <title>Obama defends leak prosecutions</title>
      <link>http://www.politico.com/blogs/under-the-radar/2016/05/obama-defends-leak-prosecutions-first-amendment-223134</link>
      <description>Obama argued that some of the cases were really the work of the Bush administration and that others involved unusually serious disclosures of classified information.</description>
      <content:encoded><p>President Barack Obama is defending the record number of leak prosecutions launched under his administration, arguing that some of the cases were really the work of the Bush administration and that others involved unusually serious disclosures of classified information.</p><p>&quot;I am a strong believer in the First Amendment and the need for journalists to pursue every lead and every angle. I think that when you hear stories about us cracking down on whistleblowers or whatnot, we’re talking about a really small sample,&quot; Obama said in <a href="http://www.dailytargum.com/article/2016/05/president-obama-sits-down-with-the-daily-targum" target="_blank">an interview published Thursday by the Rutgers University student newspaper, the Daily Targum</a>. </p><p>&quot;Many of the cases that are often lumped into, you know, my ledger, essentially were cases that were brought before we came into office. Some of them are serious, where you had purposeful leaks of information that could harm or threaten operations or individuals who were in the field involved with really sensitive national security issues,&quot; the president added.</p><p>Whistleblower and First Amendment advocates have been sharply critical of Obama over the at-least eight prosecutions brought on his watch under the Espionage Act involving suspected leaks. Before Obama took office, only three such cases had been prosecuted since the law was put on the books almost a century ago.</p><p>Obama's comment that &quot;many of the cases&quot; attributed to his administration were &quot;brought&quot; before he took office is not true in a literal sense. He appears to be echoing a talking point of Justice Department officials and others who've noted that some of the leak investigations that resulted in charges got underway before his team assumed power. </p><p>A POLITICO review of eight cases charged under Obama indicates that three appear to have been under investigation during the Bush era.</p><p>During the interview, which was conducted Monday, Obama said he's a strong proponent of First Amendment freedoms, even if he's not always fond of how the media has covered him.</p><p>&quot;The general approach that I have consistently advocated for is maximum freedom of the press. And what I’ve found personally is that — although there are times (when) it can be frustrating for a president or an administration where you feel as if the way something is reported is not accurate or is sensationalized — it is greatly preferable to the alternative. And that is something that I think we have to continue to fight for and uphold,&quot; the president said.</p><p>One prominent lawyer for whistleblowers said it was hard to assess the pace of leak prosecutions under Obama as anything but a significant increase.</p><p>&quot;This is not a really small sample. This is a tremendous uptick in whistleblower prosecutions,&quot; said Jesselyn Radack of ExposeFacts.</p><p>Radack also noted that, despite Obama's embrace of the First Amendment, prosecutors have not been willing to permit alleged leakers to mount a defense that they were performing a public service by disclosing important information to the press.</p><p>In many of the leak cases, &quot;the government filed a motion to preclude any mention of the First Amendment,&quot; she noted.</p><p>Obama is set to speak at the Rutgers commencement on Sunday.</p><br></content:encoded>

      <title>Reid: McConnell must also think women are 'dogs'</title>
      <link>http://www.politico.com/story/2016/05/harry-reid-mitch-mcconnell-women-223115</link>
      <description/>
      <content:encoded><p>Senate Minority Leader Harry Reid ridiculed Majority Leader Mitch McConnell on the Senate floor Thursday for embracing Donald Trump as the Republican Party’s presumptive presidential nominee, saying the Kentucky senator must also think women are “dogs and pigs.”</p><p>Reid's feisty comments come as the real estate mogul is in Washington for a series of conclaves with House Speaker Paul Ryan, McConnell and other congressional and party leaders.</p><p>“It’s just the latest sign that Republican leaders in both houses are marching lock step with Donald Trump,” Reid said. </p><p>McConnell told reporters last week that he had “committed to supporting the nominee chosen by Republican voters,” noting that Trump “is now on the verge of clinching the nomination.”</p><p>“I guess he should be giddy about a Trump presidency,” Reid said Thursday. “Donald Trump is everything that the Republican leader and his party could ever want in a nomination. Trump’s policy positions are identical to the Republican Party platform, and today Sen. McConnell can discuss when they meet in an hour or two that consensus with Trump.”</p><p>Reid continued tying the Senate leader to the billionaire, accusing both of being obstructionists when it comes to acting on President Barack Obama’s Supreme Court nominee and anti-women.</p><p>“Since Sen. McConnell has so enthusiastically embraced Trump, we can only assume he agrees with Trump’s view that women are dogs and pigs. We can only assume that the Republican leader is not repulsed by Donald Trump’s vulgar behavior toward women,” Reid said, pointing to an infamous interview Trump gave to Howard Stern as an example of how he views women.</p><p>Reid added that Trump and McConnell can discuss their anti-immigration views, too. Trump has called Mexicans “rapists” and vowed to build a wall on the southern border that Mexico will pay for. He also wants to deport some 11 million undocumented immigrants. He has, however, taken a step back from his proposal last year to temporarily ban Muslims from entering the U.S.</p><p>“I assume that they can have a long discussion about the wall: how high it should be, how they’re gonna get the Mexicans to pay for the wall, even though most people think the idea’s insane,” Reid said. “Let’s not forget, Republicans have demagogued Latinos and immigrants for decades. They’re doing it today.”</p><p>Reid derisively argued that Trump and McConnell will have plenty to talk about when they meet Thursday, including why the businessman should thank McConnell for his ascent to the top of the party.</p><p>“Donald Trump and the Republican leader should have a long, long conversation. They have a lot to talk about,” Reid said. “At some point in their conversation, Donald Trump should thank the senior senator from Kentucky. Trump owes his candidacy to the Republican leader and to the policies he’s led. It was an obstructionist, anti-woman, anti-Latino, anti-Muslim, anti-middle class, anti-environment and anti-Obama and anti-everything Republicans during the last eight years have made Donald Trump a reality.”</p><br></content:encoded>

      <title>Ryan's 'encouraged' after Trump meeting, but no endorsement yet</title>
      <link>http://www.politico.com/story/2016/05/paul-ryan-donald-trump-meeting-223111</link>
      <description>'This was our first meeting, but it was a very positive step toward unification,' the two said afterward.</description>
      <content:encoded><p>Paul Ryan and Donald Trump finally met. And they decided to have more meetings. </p><p>The highly anticipated summit Thursday between the top Republican elected official in the country and the GOP's presumptive presidential nominee produced a media frenzy, but yielded little in the way of tangible results.</p><p>Ryan, as expected, didn't endorse Trump. And it's clear major policy differences remain. But for now, the two are trying to display unity as they prepare for a fall battle with Hillary Clinton and the Democrats. With Republican control of the Senate on the line, as well as fears that Democrats could make big inroads into the House Republican majority — much less the battle for the White House itself — the stakes for both men are enormous. They need to find some means to cooperate, or at least appear amicable.</p><p>&quot;The United States cannot afford another four years of the Obama White House, which is what Hillary Clinton represents. That is why it’s critical that Republicans unite around our shared principles, advance a conservative agenda, and do all we can to win this fall,&quot; Trump and Ryan said in a joint statement following their hourlong meeting. Republican National Committee Chairman Reince Priebus hosted the session.</p><p>&quot;While we were honest about our few differences, we recognize that there are also many important areas of common ground. We will be having additional discussions, but remain confident there’s a great opportunity to unify our party and win this fall, and we are totally committed to working together to achieve that goal. </p><p>Ryan and Trump added: &quot;This was our first meeting, but it was a very positive step toward unification.&quot;</p><p>At a news conference afterward, Ryan repeatedly ducked the question of whether he would formally back Trump, and if so, when.</p><p>He also made clear that he and Trump are still on different pages policy-wise, though he didn't get into details.</p><p><button class="enhancement" data-id="00000154-a5c7-da04-a3ff-bddfea5d0000" data-reference="{&quot;label&quot;:&quot;Hill GOP horrified, awestruck by Trump\r\n&quot;,&quot;record&quot;:{&quot;_ref&quot;:&quot;00000154-a5c7-da04-a3ff-bddfea5d0000&quot;,&quot;_type&quot;:&quot;0000014f-2902-d3ee-ab5f-ffef6efc0000&quot;},&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;00000154-a5c8-dd11-affc-f7de137d0000&quot;,&quot;_type&quot;:&quot;0000014b-324d-d4f3-a3cb-f3ff41570003&quot;}">Hill GOP horrified, awestruck by Trump
</button>&quot;Look, it's no secret that Donald Trump and I have had our differences. We talked about those differences today. That's common knowledge,&quot; Ryan told reporters.  &quot;The question is what is it that we need to do to unify the Republican Party and all strains of conservative wings in the party. We had a very good and encouraging, productive conversation on how to do that.&quot;</p><p>&quot;I was very encouraged by what I heard from Donald Trump today,&quot; Ryan added. &quot;This is a process, it takes a little time. You don't put it together in 45 minutes.&quot;</p><p>Trump took to his favorite medium, Twitter, to rave about his trip to Capitol Hill.</p><p>&quot;Great day in D.C. with <a href="https://twitter.com/SpeakerRyan" target="_blank">@<b>SpeakerRyan</b></a> and Republican leadership. Things working out really well! #Trump2016,&quot; he wrote.</p><p>Ryan acknowledged that there are bitter divisions within the party, and the schisms aren't going to magically disappear overnight.</p><p>&quot;The process of unifying the Republican Party, which just finished a primary about a week ago, perhaps one of the most divisive primaries in memory, takes some time,&quot; Ryan said. &quot;Look, there are people who were for Donald Trump, who were for Ted Cruz, for John Kasich, who were for Marco Rubio and everybody else, and it's very important that we don't fake unifying, we don't pretend unification.&quot;</p><p>Since Ryan has pointedly refused to endorse Trump so far — and has publicly challenged Trump several times over the former reality TV star's harsh rhetoric and controversial stances — Thursday's meeting was seen as a critical moment for the Wisconsin Republican, who has been widely talked about as a future presidential candidate himself.</p><p>Would Ryan become a loyal member of Trump’s Republican Party? Or would Ryan keep his distance from the bombastic GOP nominee, bucking much of the political establishment in an attempt to keep his brand intact?</p><p>It remains clear that Ryan will never fully embrace the Republican Party’s nominee, and is instead focused on his own policy agenda. Ryan will spend much of 2016 campaigning to keep the House majority and seek to avoid the daily back-and-forth of the presidential race.</p><p>Ryan, though, has found himself increasingly boxed in. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.), House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy (R-Calif.) and House Majority Whip Steve Scalise (R-La.) have all endorsed Trump. National Republican Congressional Committee Chairman Greg Walden (R-Ore.), in a statement Thursday, called Trump &quot;the better option.&quot; </p><p>And on Wednesday evening, House Rules Chairman Pete Sessions (R-Texas), House Budget Chairman Tom Price (R-Ga.), House Agriculture Chairman Mike Conaway (R-Texas) and House Science, Space and Technology Chairman Lamar Smith (R-Texas) backed Trump. Price is a longtime political ally of Ryan’s.</p><br><p>Ryan personifies the split inside the Republican Party caused by Trump's stunning rise during the past year. Ryan, the 2012 GOP vice presidential nominee, is a serious policy wonk who has made a career out of building an image as a Ronald Reagan-Jack Kemp hybrid — ideologically stringent but with a sunny disposition. Trump, on the other hand, is an uber-rich political showman who has rejected much of the conservative agenda for his own cult of personality built on his assertion that he will make America and Americans winners again somehow.</p><p>Priebus, who sat in on the session, described the meeting on Twitter as &quot;great. It was a very positive step toward party unity.&quot;</p><p>Ryan's colleagues, even those who back Trump, know he is going to proceed carefully in his dealings with the real estate mogul.</p><p>&quot;Paul Ryan is not the kind of individual that after a single meeting is going to say, 'OK, now I understand everything I need to do, give me the flag, I'm going to go start running forward,'&quot; Rep. Chris Collins (R-N.Y.) told CNN before the meeting.</p><p>As with any Trump appearance — but especially one with the stakes of today's event — there were hordes of media present, as well as pro and anti-Trump protesters.</p><p>Before Trump's arrival at the RNC building — he and Ryan went in the back door — a group of Hispanic protesters stood in front of the GOP headquarters bashing Trump's stand on undocumented immigrants. They chanted over a white and red banner that read &quot;United We Dream&quot; and &quot;End Deportation.&quot; Others held signs that read &quot;The GOP: The Party of Trump.&quot; Or &quot;Rabbis Against Trump.&quot;</p><p>&quot;Make way for Donald Trump!&quot; claimed another protester holding a pink sign that read &quot;Trump is a Racist.&quot; Following her was a man in an oversize papier-m&acirc;ch&eacute; mask of Trump, carrying money bags. </p><p>Security was tight around GOP headquarters as Trump's meetings with GOP brass kicked off.<b> </b>A wall of Secret Service agents and U.S. Capitol Police officers kept reporters and and protesters away from the entrance used by Trump and Ryan.</p><p>The Ryan-Trump t&ecirc;te-&agrave;-t&ecirc;te began promptly at 9 a.m. By 9:30, McCarthy and the rest of the House GOP leadership team had slipped into RNC headquarters as well. The broader meeting began at 10 and lasted for 35 minutes.</p><p>McConnell and Senate GOP leaders were set to met with Trump after that.</p><p>The spectacle — hundreds of reporters and TV cameras, as well as the protesters only a couple blocks from the Capitol — was too much to resist, even for lawmakers.</p><p>Former Rep. Phil Gingrey (R-Ga.), now a lobbyist, stood on the sidewalk gawking like everyone else.  House Judiciary Committee Chairman Bob Goodlatte (R-Va.) stopped to snap a photo of the scene with his phone. </p><p><i>Rachael Bade contributed to this report.</i><br /></p><br><br></content:encoded>

      <title>Top Trump ally on Capitol Hill: He snubbed us</title>
      <link>http://www.politico.com/story/2016/05/duncan-hunter-trump-snub-223126</link>
      <description/>
      <content:encoded><p>One of Donald Trump's top allies in Congress slammed the presumptive GOP nominee after he failed to meet with rank-and-file lawmakers backing his campaign during his ballyhooed trip to Capitol Hill on Thursday.</p><p>Rep. Duncan Hunter (R-Calif.) told POLITICO that Trump refused multiple requests to meet with members of Congress working to round up support for him in Washington.</p><p>“I think it would have been good of him&quot; to meet with &quot;the first endorsers,&quot; Hunter said, as well as those who've gotten on board more recently, Hunter said. “There is no reason not to have as many people on your side as you can … and he missed a real opportunity here.”</p><p>Trump met with House Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wis.), Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) and several others in leadership during a series of meetings on Thursday morning. </p><p>His most ardent congressional backers, however, asked his campaign several times for a few minutes with the candidate, too. They thought it would energize the team running traps to whip support for him in Washington. They also wanted Trump to meet with a core group of committee chairs they thought would make for powerful future allies.</p><p>Hunter said the complaint isn't about his ego, contending that face time with rank-and-file lawmakers would actually have helped Trump in the long run by making it easier for them to vouch for the candidate with voters in their districts.</p><p>“If they endorse him, then go back to their districts to say they’ve met him and he’s not crazy, it goes a long way,” Hunter said. “It helps if you can say, 'I met the guy' ... and can be beneficial for Trump, too.”</p> <p>An aide to another Republican lawmaker backing Trump, however, called Hunter's criticism a bit much. </p><p>&quot;These concerns about access are overblown. The early endorsers have had a number of opportunities to meet and talk with Donald Trump. Today’s meetings with Speaker Ryan and the House Leadership are direct outgrowth of those discussions,&quot; the aide said. &quot;It is expected that Mr. Trump will be in Washington a great deal in the weeks ahead, providing new opportunities for members to continue their dialogue.&quot;</p><br></content:encoded>

      <title>Trump to Senate GOP: I get your concerns</title>
      <link>http://www.politico.com/story/2016/05/trump-meets-senate-republicans-223118</link>
      <description/>
      <content:encoded><p>The Republican senators that met with Donald Trump on Thursday were united by a shared concern: Trump’s tone and rhetoric. </p> <p>Several lawmakers gently told him that what he says and how he says it matters, both for Trump’s general election campaign and their own chances of keeping the Senate. Trump was in “listening mode,” attendees at the meeting told POLITICO, but gave them the answer that they wanted to hear.</p> <p>“I get that,” Trump told the nearly dozen senators in attendance. Most of them were relieved to hear it.</p> <p>Trump also told senators that he would help raise money in the battle to retain the Senate, which further buoyed Republicans worried about whether he will be a down-ballot drag. In other words, it was a major step forward for the divided party, senators said.</p> <p>“He was very, very congenial, very straightforward, very open to questions, criticisms and so forth,” Sen. Orrin Hatch (R-Utah) said. “He was terrific. I’ll tell you, I was really quite impressed.”</p> <p>Trump and key aides huddled with Senate GOP leaders and party officials on Thursday morning to discuss coordinating the Senate and presidential campaigns as well as policy matters. For many senators, it was their first lengthy face-to-face meeting with their nominee, and they came away more confident that Trump will help them keep the Senate — not lose it.</p> <p>“Obviously he’s never run for public office before and so this is a new experience for him and for us,” said Senate Majority Whip John Cornyn of Texas. “He recognized the impact of the presidential candidate on down-ballot races and said he looked forward to being helpful when he could.”</p> <p>On Thursday morning Trump — accompanied by convention manager Paul Manafort and campaign manager Corey Lewandowski — met privately with Ward Baker, the executive director of the National Republican Senatorial Committee, and Sharon Soderstrom, chief of staff for Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.), according to a GOP source. The topic at hand was how the two sides could work together this campaign season.</p> <p>McConnell and his leadership team then huddled with Trump, who left at around 12:45 p.m. with a wave at the press mob. There was no media availability.</p> <p>&quot;We had a very good meeting. Very good, constructive meeting,&quot; McConnell told reporters. &quot;We talked about a variety of things, both campaign related and issues.&quot;</p> <p>GOP leaders then gave a quick presentation to the full 54-member Republican caucus at lunch, informing them that in their view, Trump seemed interested in working with them. </p> <p>In the meeting between senators and the GOP nominee, lawmakers mixed policy with politics as Trump sat back and listened — one attendee said that Trump spoke less than half the time during the meeting with senators. </p><p>“It was better than expected … he was not just listening he was responding,” said one attendee. “It was not antagonistic. It was positive. There was a discussion of differences of some issues.”</p> <p>All the Senate Republicans who attended the meeting also took turns taking a photo with Trump, with the presumptive nominee giving a thumbs-up in all the pictures, another source familiar with the meeting said.</p> <p>Cornyn encouraged Trump to attend the Texas Republican Convention this weekend, though Trump's handlers shook their heads &quot;no&quot; as Trump expressed interest in taking Cornyn's advice. The Texas senator also offered to be an adviser in attracting the Latino vote after winning reelection in Texas in 2014 — an overture that reflects many Republicans’ concerns with his statements that many people that come over the southern border are “rapists” and “murderers.” </p><p>And Trump is even reaching out to his harshest critics. After Trump requested his national security expertise, Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.) said he spoke to Trump on Wednesday, even though he still won’t vote for the business mogul. The conversation was “very cordial, funny,” Graham said. </p> <p>“He’s got a great sense of humor. He’s from New York, he obviously can take a punch,” Graham told reporters. “I wished him well and that’s where we are.”</p> <p> House Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) set the tone early on Thursday, issuing a diplomatic joint statement with Trump after their morning meeting. And Republican senators stayed on message as well, praising the sit-down and offering generalities about working together with a nominee who's at odds with party leaders' views on trade, Planned Parenthood, health care and foreign policy.</p> <p>Participants in the meeting talked about &quot;all sorts of things. It was a good meeting,&quot; said Sen. Deb Fischer (R-Neb.).</p> <p>Republican senators who attended the meeting: McConnell; Cornyn; Conference Chairman John Thune of South Dakota; Policy Chairman John Barrasso of Wyoming; Conference Vice-Chair Roy Blunt of Missouri; NRSC Chair Roger Wicker of Mississippi; Senate President Pro Tem Hatch; Rob Portman of Ohio;  Shelley Moore Capito of West Virginia; and Fischer.</p> <p>Portman, Capito and Fischer are three of McConnell's four counsels to leadership. The fourth, Sen. Mike Lee of Utah, was not invited to the meeting.</p><p>Sen. Jeff Sessions of Alabama, the only Republican senator to endorse Trump while the primary was still being contested, also attended the meeting. He declined to comment.</p><br></content:encoded>

      <title>Trump splits Ryan and McConnell</title>
      <link>http://www.politico.com/story/2016/05/trump-ryan-mcconnell-223091</link>
      <description>The two GOP leaders are taking very different approaches to the nominee — in part because McConnell is fighting for his majority.</description>
      <content:encoded><p>Mitch McConnell and Paul Ryan are the two most powerful people in the Republican Party after Donald Trump. And they couldn’t be handling him more differently.</p><p>On Thursday morning, the two leaders will come face-to-face with Trump on Capitol Hill as the party lurches toward the general election. But in the days leading up to the meeting, they’ve taken divergent approaches toward the billionaire mogul and presumptive nominee: McConnell has moved cautiously, offering a lukewarm endorsement while staying out of the limelight. Ryan, on the other hand, has publicly challenged Trump to change his ways, while withholding his endorsement.</p><p>At one level, the Senate majority leader and House speaker have a generational, ideological and temperamental gulf between them that explains the sharp difference in tone and strategy. Beyond that, however, the unique political circumstances of the House and Senate are driving the split approach.</p><p>McConnell faces a stiff challenge to defend his Senate majority, working off a map filled with purple states that could relegate the GOP leader to the minority if Trump supporters turn their backs on incumbent Republicans in states like Ohio, New Hampshire and Pennsylvania. Ryan faces little threat of losing the House, yet has a slate of members from conservatives to moderates who have shown real disgust for Trump’s rhetoric and his policy proposals.</p><p>“Ryan’s got a conference with a lot of diverse interests and points of view … he’s got a lot of people in his conference in districts where maybe Trump doesn’t poll well. I think he’ll eventually come around to where Mitch is,” said Sen. John Thune of South Dakota, the No. 3 leader and a former House colleague of Ryan’s. “Both are thinking about their conference and what’s best for them.”</p><p>Blink and you may have missed the key moment for McConnell. One day before Ryan refused to endorse Trump on national TV, McConnell quietly laid out his rationale for offering a tepid endorsement in a news statement: He had long committed to supporting the nominee and Trump was now the guy. It didn’t get a lot of buzz, and neither did his remarks Tuesday in which he offered facts rather than opinions, concluding that Trump “got more votes than anybody else.”</p><p>McConnell has gone to great, and occasionally awkward, lengths to avoid responding to the daily rhythm of the presidential race this year. But McConnell’s allies say that his dispassionate assessment of the presidential race may now be an asset in working with Trump.</p><p>“He did the only logical thing … there’s not a lot of other options there,” said Senate Majority Whip John Cornyn (R-Texas). “We just need to accept the reality. Which is: He’s going to be the nominee, we would like to maintain the majority in the Senate and the House and we need to figure ways to maximize our chances of winning in November.”</p><p>It’s not like McConnell is a close buddy with Trump, like Ryan’s predecessor John Boehner. McConnell has not spoken with Trump since March, when he told the presidential candidate to tone down the violent atmosphere at some of his rallies. Declining to name Trump, McConnell also scolded him for not repudiating David Duke and said his plan to ban Muslims was “inconsistent” with American values.</p><p>Trump, meanwhile, chided McConnell in 2013 on Twitter for not pursuing a bigger fiscal deal with President Barack Obama but called McConnell a “good guy” while attacking Cruz last month for calling McConnell a liar. While no one would mistake McConnell for a Trump cheerleader, he’s also been careful not to antagonize him — a strategy that accommodates the diverse views of his members, from the “Never Trump” senators like Lindsey Graham of South Carolina to the Trump boosters like Jeff Sessions of Alabama.</p><p>“As a leader, you have to manage your team in a way that respects and recognizes that there may be differences of opinion,” said Sen. Dan Coats (R-Ind.). “He’s very, very good at that.”</p><p>And allies say McConnell’s careful management of Trump’s rise gives the GOP leader some political capital with the presumptive nominee as his members figure out how to run alongside Trump in diverse and liberal-leaning states.</p><p>McConnell has “preserved his ability to have a seat at the table without embracing the more problematic parts of his platform,” said one person close to McConnell.</p><p>Ryan, on the other hand, has been the most outspoken Republican leader on Capitol Hill while disavowing Trump’s tone and proposals. He’s openly talked to colleagues about how some of Trump’s policy pitches — trade barriers, minimum wage increases, kicking undocumented immigrants out of the nation — are not in line with his agenda. He’s gone on national television saying he’s not sure Trump is an authentic “standard-bearer for conservatives.”</p><p>“Paul’s a policy guy — it’s well known,” said Rep. Steve Womack of Arkansas, who wants the party to rally around Trump. “And I think his support is driven in many respects by the policies someone lays out, but we haven’t seen a lot of policy from Donald Trump. So I think it’s understandable that Paul would be a little hesitant right now.”</p><p>The 46-year-old speaker — who, many believe, could run for president in 2020 — feels it’s his duty to protect the party’s future. And he wants to set himself up as an alternative to Trump should a backlash occur against the New Yorker.</p><p>McConnell, 74, already has his dream job and won’t, of course, be president — but he has to manage many colleagues who would like to be one day. That means tolerating a range of opinion different from that of endangered House members who worry Trump will carry them out of office. Graham isn’t attacking Trump because he could lose his seat; he’s doing it because he believes Trump is a disaster for the party.</p><p>Senators say McConnell rarely discusses Trump in caucus meetings and doesn’t tell senators how to discuss him either.</p><p>“It’s not that I don’t respect where he is, but it’s kind of an individual thing. There really isn’t a conference position on that,” said Sen. Jeff Flake (R-Ariz.), who is withholding his endorsement of Trump.</p><p>Georgia Republican Rep. Lynn Westmoreland — who has spoken plainly about his disapproval of Ryan’s bombshell interview last week — says Ryan has a bit more leverage than McConnell, which may motivate his “hard-to-get” play. The Senate leader, he said, will need a President Trump to help whip upper-chamber support to meet its higher 60-vote threshold on any GOP legislation. But a President Trump would need Ryan’s wonkish expertise to figure out the policy nuts and bolts.</p><p>“McConnell will need Trump’s help to get anything passed in the Senate,” Westmoreland said. But “if Trump really wants to come in here and do something about reforming taxes or cutting spending, then Paul Ryan has got to be his guy over here.”<br /></p><br><br><br><br></content:encoded>

      <title>House GOP budget still dead in the water</title>
      <link>http://www.politico.com/story/2016/05/house-gop-budget-votes-223143</link>
      <description/>
      <content:encoded><p>House Republicans still don’t have the votes to pass a budget and GOP leaders are trying to figure out their next move.</p><p>House Majority Whip Steve Scalise’s (R-La.) team did a whip check on Thursday. While the check wasn't completed, it was clear that Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) and other top Republicans didn’t have the votes to move a budget through, according to multiple leadership sources.</p><p>There is now a possibility that Ryan and House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy (R-Calif.) will start moving spending bills to the floor next week without passing a budget first — a decision that could prove embarrassing for a former Budget Chairman like Ryan. After May 15, the House may act on appropriations bills without passing a budget, although one GOP insider said leaders are also considering passing the blueprint after they begin work on individual appropriations bills.</p><p>“We’re still working on it,” Conference Chair Cathy McMorris Rodgers told POLITICO. “We’ve got some work to do.”</p><br><p>Leadership is trying to muster enough votes from conservatives to pass their $1.07 trillion budget — the level put in place last year under a deal inked by President Barack Obama and then-Speaker John Boehner. That’s why they’re adding so-called “side car” items to the budget, which aim to trim spending on mandatory programs like Medicaid, but would be very unlikely to be signed into law by Obama.</p><p>But some conservatives, who favor a lower spending number for federal agencies for fiscal 2017, still aren’t buying what leadership is selling. Rep. Dave Brat, a member of the House Freedom Caucus, for example, said he would vote against the budget “until the deficit comes down from $535 billion.” </p><p>And fellow conservative Rep. David Schweikert said he was still undecided. “There are a couple mechanics that I need a little more detail on,” the Arizona Republican said. “And I have one request in the order of something. I’m going to see if there’s a chance that could be done.”</p><p>Given that the Boehner-Obama deal called for slight increases in this year's spending bills, Republicans will likely need to rely on Democrats to pass the 12 appropriations measures, as many conservatives have warned they won’t vote for them. That opens up a new problem for Ryan: a question of how many Democrats will actually back the funding bills, especially if those bills are loaded with conservative policy riders — and what would he need to do to get their votes?</p><br><p>In an effort to restart the budget process ahead of those spending bills, leadership’s latest pitch to conservatives included an idea by Rep. Morgan Griffith (R-Va.) to “weld” together the budget resolution with $30 billion in mandatory savings — essentially offsetting the bipartisan spending boost passed last year that conservatives abhor. The second piece included a pitch by Rep. Tom McClintock (R-Calif.) to changes rules in the future to stop programs whose authorizations have expired from receiving any new funds.</p><p>Some conservatives sound like they may be coming around.</p><p>“I’m considering it more favorably than I thought I would,” said Rep. Cynthia Lummis (R-Wyo.), also a member of the House Freedom Caucus.</p><p>Still, she’s undecided, and said reservations linger: “I’m hearing people say, ‘It’s not going to even get to the president’s desk, so it’s window dressing.’ … I’m going to think about it awhile longer.”</p><p>Rep. Tim Murphy (R-Pa.), had his own demand before he would get to ‘yes.’ He told the whip team: “I’m waiting for my mental health bill.”</p><p>Even appropriators like Rep. Charlie Dent (R-Pa.) say they’re still sorting through the new deal. Dent previously supported the $1.07 trillion top-line without any additional savings and has authored his Military Construction-Veterans Affairs spending bill based on that level. Dent said he’s hopeful the appropriations bill will head to the floor next week, with or without budget.</p><br></content:encoded>

      <title>Koch-backed group targets first GOP incumbent in primary</title>
      <link>http://www.politico.com/story/2016/05/koch-group-targets-renee-ellmers-223124</link>
      <description/>
      <content:encoded><p>Americans for Prosperity is planning a major expenditure to defeat North Carolina Republican Rep. <a href="https://cd.politicopro.com/people/151843" target="_blank">Renee Ellmers</a> in her June primary, an unprecedented move for the powerful Koch brothers-backed conservative nonprofit, which has never targeted a GOP member of Congress for primary defeat. </p> <p>“Rep. Renee Ellmers has sadly become a part of the very Washington she once claimed she wanted to fix,&quot; said AFP President Tim Phillips. “After giving Rep. Ellmers every chance to match her votes to her prior rhetoric, she’s demonstrated an unacceptable pattern of supporting wasteful government spending and corporate welfare. North Carolinians deserve a true conservative who will fight for them, not special interests.&quot; </p> <p>AFP plans to target voters in Ellmers’ district with six-figures worth of advertising, including five to eight separate mailers, as well as digital ads on streaming platforms, like YouTube, Facebook and Hulu, in the four weeks leading up to the June 7 primary. Ellmers faces fellow GOP Rep. <a href="https://cd.politicopro.com/people/70574" target="_blank">George Holding</a> and two-time Senate candidate Greg Brannon in the Republican race for a newly drawn seat anchored in the Raleigh suburbs, which was created by court-ordered redistricting earlier this year.</p> <p>Most of AFP’s political spending targets Democrats — in 2013 and 2014, the group blitzed Democratic senators with tens of millions of dollars in early attack ads on health care and other subjects. It rarely gets involved in major Republican primaries. In 2014, the group spent hundreds of thousands of dollars supporting GOP Rep. <a href="https://cd.politicopro.com/people/158348" target="_blank">Mike Pompeo</a>, whose Wichita, Kansas-based district includes the Koch Industries headquarters, against a primary challenger.</p> <p>AFP’s first foray into anti-incumbent primary spending comes in a state where the group has its deepest roots. North Carolina was one of the first states where AFP opened a chapter office in 2004. The state division of the group now has 12 full-time staffers and eight field directors, who will conduct a grass-roots persuasion campaign against Ellmers, as well.</p> <p>Ellmers would have seemed an unusual target for conservative ire when she swept into Congress on the tea party wave in 2010. In 2012, the former nurse even appeared at an AFP Hands Off Our Healthcare rally.</p> <br><p> But critics say that Ellmers quickly became a leadership ally and establishment member since she arrived in Washington. The Club for Growth, another conservative organization, is opposing her in a second consecutive election, and Ellmers has <a href="http://www.politico.com/story/2016/03/renee-ellmers-anti-abortion-groups-221296" target="_blank">clashed with anti-abortion groups,</a> as well. And AFP has called out Ellmers for votes, including one last year to reauthorize the Export-Import Bank, an issue that became a major point of contention within the Republican Party.</p> <p> AFP is not endorsing any of Ellmers' opponents, the group says. But it does directly contrast Ellmers and Holding in one of the ads.</p> <p> “Americans balance their budgets, work hard. Renee Ellmers promised to do the same, but she became a part of the Washington problem,” <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4kfIFeFHwRM&amp;feature=youtu.be" target="_blank">the ad’s narrator says</a>. “She promised spending limits, then voted against them. She ran against special interest deals, then voted for them. But George Holding kept his word. Opposing wasteful spending, protecting taxpayers, standing up to special interests.”</p> <p> “Vote ‘no’ on Renee Ellmers,” the narrator finishes. </p> <p> Ellmers said in an interview last week that she is the same candidate she was in 2010, and that she has kept the promises she made to voters.</p> <p> “I’ve stood on the principles that I was running on [in 2010] and I have held on to them. There are people out there who were of a different mindset, assuming their form of conservatism and my form of conservatism were the same, but mine is more common sense conservatism,” Ellmers said. “I don’t know how voting ‘no’ all the time makes you more conservative.”</p> <p> AFP’s spending will pile onto other anti-Ellmers outside efforts ahead of June 7. The Club for Growth recently announced plans to spend money opposing her, too.</p> <br><p> &quot;Renee Ellmers first ran as a tea party conservative, but has become an establishment liberal in Washington,&quot; Club for Growth President David McIntosh said in statement. &quot;With a lifetime Club for Growth rating of 60 percent and a 2015 score of 57 percent, Ellmers is clearly betraying the conservative values of her constituents.&quot;</p> <p> Ellmers said she doesn’t make decisions based on “outside group scorecards.” </p> <p> “[Club for Growth] has no control over me, as they do over my opponent. They’ve been coming at me in various ways since 2013,” Ellmers said. “It’s an opportunity for me to highlight the doers against the ones who sit back and take a pass on everything and wait for the special interest groups to tell them what to do.”</p> <p> Ellmers’ outgunned campaign is fighting back. It released a radio ad Thursday attacking Holding for<b> </b>a recent &quot;first-class trip to Jordan,&quot; a spokesman for Ellmers confirmed.</p> <p> “For Congress, we have a choice between a man who fancies cheese tortellini … and one powerful conservative in Renee Ellmers,” the radio ad says. “George Holding voted against the farm bill, against military funding to defeat ISIS. But Holding voted for cheese tortellini when selecting his meal for a recent first-class ticket on a trans-Atlantic flight that he billed to you, the taxpayer.” </p><p><i>Eli Stokols contributed reporting. </i></p> <br></content:encoded>

      <title>House GOP wins Obamacare lawsuit</title>
      <link>http://www.politico.com/story/2016/05/house-gop-wins-obamacare-lawsuit-223121</link>
      <description/>
      <content:encoded><p>A federal judge on Thursday ruled the Obama administration has been improperly funding an Obamacare subsidy program, a huge win for the House of Representatives in a lawsuit against the White House.</p><p>Congress authorized the program but never actually provided the money for it, wrote U.S. District Court Judge Rosemary M. Collyer. The program will be allowed to continue, pending appeal. </p><p>&quot;Congress is the only source for such an appropriation, and no public money can be spent without one,” wrote Collyer, a George W. Bush appointee.</p><p>The ruling, if it stands, could be a significant financial setback for the millions of low-income Americans who benefit from the cost-sharing subsidies, which help people pay for out-of-pocket costs like co-pays at a doctor’s office. It would not be a fatal blow to the future of the president’s signature domestic policy achievement, but it could push insurance costs higher. </p><p>Republicans have praised the challenge as a needed check on the White House's authority. </p><p>&quot;This decision is a critical step in protecting Congress' power of the purse from an administration that has repeatedly ignored a fundamental principle of our Republic: the separation of powers,&quot; said House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Kevin Brady. </p><p>The Obama administration is expected to immediately appeal the decision to the D.C. Circuit Court of Appeals.</p><p>&quot;This is not the first time that we’ve seen opponents of the Affordable Care Act go through the motions to try to win this political fight in the court system,&quot; said White House press secretary Josh Earnest. </p><p>The health care law was designed to reimburse insurers for providing the cost-sharing subsidies to low-income customers who purchased exchange coverage. A second Obamacare subsidy program helping customers pay monthly premiums wasn't a target in the House lawsuit. </p><p>The House argues that the cost-sharing program was authorized but never appropriated. The House says that there is proof that the White House knew the cost-sharing subsidies weren’t funded and worked around the legislation to implement them. </p><p>The White House asked Congress to fund the program in its fiscal 2014 budget request, which was denied. It then unilaterally funded the program through the refundable tax credit account anyway, the House lawyers argued in court.</p><p>When he filed the <i>House v. Burwell </i>lawsuit two years ago, former House Speaker John Boehner framed it as a check on the executive branch’s ability to change legislation once it was approved by Congress. </p><p>But the Justice Department says the subsidies were funded appropriately. Its lawyers told the court that the program was funded in the same pot of money as the law’s refundable tax credits to help people pay for premiums.</p><p>Part of the Obama administration’s defense is that the health law was not written well — an argument it also made during prior Obamacare legal battles.</p><p>The Obama administration argued that the budget request cited by the House isn’t proof of malfeasance. Justice Department lawyers said the request did not fully account for “text, structure, design and history of the ACA — a complex statute that the Supreme Court recently described as containing ‘more than a few examples of inartful drafting.'”</p><p>The Obama administration also heavily relied on last year's Supreme Court decision in <i>King v. Burwell </i>— which was centered on the health law’s premium subsidies — to stress that a court must look at an entire law, not specific provisions. It says that the two subsidy programs were designed to work together as one.</p><p>The cost-sharing subsidies are available to people with incomes between the federal poverty level and 250 percent FPL — or between $24,300 and $60,750 for a family of four — to help pay for health care services. </p><p>Several million Obamacare customers receive cost-sharing subsidies, but the exact figure is unknown. As of the middle of the last Obamacare enrollment period, <a href="https://aspe.hhs.gov/sites/default/files/pdf/167986/MarketPlaceAddendumJan2016.pdf" target="_blank">57 percent</a> of people who signed up for coverage through the federal exchange on HealthCare.gov receive them. </p><p>If the cost-sharing subsidies are eliminated, government actuaries estimate that insurers would <a href="https://aspe.hhs.gov/sites/default/files/pdf/156571/ASPE_IB_CSRs.pdf" target="_blank">increase premiums</a> — up to 20 percent to 30 percent for silver-tiered plans — to make up for the loss. As a result, the premium tax credits would increase, at a higher cost to the federal government, according to the Department of Health and Human Services. </p><p>Insurers downplayed the ruling Thursday. &quot;There is a long judicial process ahead before a final decision is made,&quot; said Marilyn Tavenner, CEO of America's Health Insurance Plans, the industry's main lobbying group. &quot;Our members' focus is and will remain on serving consumers — to ensure their coverage is protected and their health care choices are maintained.&quot; </p><p>If the subsidies are ultimately struck, it would reinforce claims from opponents of the health law that the Obamacare insurance plans are not actually affordable.</p><p>The House originally wanted to challenge both the cost-sharing subsidies and the executive branch’s changes to Obamacare’s employer mandate. But the mandate challenges were tossed in an earlier court ruling.</p><p>The administration had tried to get the case thrown out on procedural grounds, contending that the House can’t bring litigation against the executive branch. But in September, <a href="http://www.politico.com/story/2015/09/house-obamacare-lawsuit-cost-sharing-subsidies-213465" target="_blank">Collyer allowed the suit to proceed.</a></p><p>At the time, the White House and legal allies slammed the decision as unprecedented, arguing that this was a political battle, not a legal one. </p><p>The suit is the latest in what has been a persistent series of legal challenges for Obamacare. The Supreme Court has ruled twice in the law’s favor. In 2012, it upheld the individual mandate and, in 2015, it upheld the premium tax credits.</p><p>In 2014, the justices said that closely held companies don’t have to provide birth control under the law if they have religious objections. The court is now considering a similar challenge from nonprofit organizations with religious ties.</p><p><i>Nick Gass contributed to this report. </i><br /></p><br><br></content:encoded>

      <title>Rubio enlists James Baker to knock Trump</title>
      <link>http://www.politico.com/story/2016/05/marco-rubio-james-baker-donald-trump-223142</link>
      <description/>
      <content:encoded><p>Marco Rubio’s latest shot at Donald Trump came with an assist from James Baker.</p><p>The Republican Florida senator, who abandoned the presidential race earlier this year after repeated drubbings by Trump, asked the revered GOP elder statesman on Thursday what he thought of suggestions by “some people” that more countries should have nuclear weapons.</p><p>“The more countries that acquire nuclear weapons, the more instability there is going to be in the world,” replied Baker, a former secretary of state, during a Senate Foreign Relations Committee hearing.</p><p>Trump has said he’s open to the idea of Japan, South Korea and even Saudi Arabia having their own nuclear defenses, instead of relying on America’s security umbrella.</p><p>Baker was testifying during a session titled “Examining America’s Role in the World.” And although he didn’t talk about Trump directly, it was clear that Baker wasn’t in line with the GOP presidential front-runner’s foreign policy ideas. (However, Baker met with Trump and his advisers later Thursday at the Jones Day law firm.)</p><p>Trump, for instance, has questioned the usefulness of NATO, and whether the U.S. is carrying too much of the security alliance’s burden. But Baker stressed that international alliances are important and actually “strengthen America.”</p><p>Baker, considered a realist in foreign policy circles, promoted what he called “selective engagement,” a paradigm that appears to call on the U.S. to evaluate international crises on a case-by-case basis, with a focus on protecting its vital interests while keeping a high bar for military intervention.</p><br><p>“The approach I suggest does not fall easily into traditional categories of foreign policy — that is: ‘realism’ or ‘idealism,’” Baker said in his written testimony. “It contains the ‘best elements of both.’ And it represents one of our most distinctive national characteristics: We are a practical people less interested in ideological purity than in solving problems.&quot;</p><p>Baker is a long-time ally of the Bush family, and it’s unlikely he would have kind words for Trump. Jeb Bush, the son of former President George H.W. Bush, quit the presidential race but has said he will not endorse Trump to be his party’s nominee.</p><p>The hearing was organized by Republican Sen. Bob Corker of Tennessee, the committee's chairman. </p><p>Corker has recently spoken out favorably about Trump's foreign policy ideas, suggesting the real estate mogul has been influenced by Baker, even though many observers say the real estate mogul is incoherent on international issues. As a result of his kind words for Trump, some have been floating Corker as a potential vice presidential pick.<br /></p><br></content:encoded>

      <title>Boehner: 'Anyone who thinks Donald Trump can't win, just watch'</title>
      <link>http://www.politico.com/story/2016/05/john-boehner-trump-can-win-223122</link>
      <description/>
      <content:encoded><p>As his successor was trying to <a href="http://www.politico.com/story/2016/05/paul-ryan-donald-trump-meeting-223111" target="_blank">work through his disagreements </a>with Donald Trump on Capitol Hill on Thursday, John Boehner was sounding off on the GOP's presumptive nominee from 2,400 miles away.</p><p>The former House speaker said at the SkyBridge Alternatives Conference on Thursday that Trump is the nominee &quot;whether people like it or not,&quot; the AP <a href="http://bigstory.ap.org/773211d1ffba41c5a45574db0b093ae0" target="_blank">reported</a>. </p><p>&quot;Anyone who thinks Donald Trump can't win, just watch,&quot; Boehner said at the Las Vegas gathering. </p><p>Current House Speaker Paul Ryan, Boehner explained, is &quot;trying to help shape the direction of Trump's policies.&quot; And the retired Ohio lawmaker said he himself doesn't support Trump's policies on Muslims and trade deals, but suggested they weren't enough to break with the new face of the Republican Party.</p><p>Boehner did say he was thankful Ted Cruz didn't win the nomination.</p><p>&quot;Thank God that guy from Texas didn’t win,” he said, according to The Wall Street Journal, noting that he drew criticism for giving the devil a &quot;bad name&quot; by <a href="http://www.politico.com/story/2016/04/john-beohner-ted-cruz-lucifer-222570" target="_blank">referring to</a> Cruz as &quot;Lucifer in the flesh&quot; last month. &quot;I have Democrat friends and Republican friends. I get along with almost everyone, but I have never worked with a more miserable son of a bitch in my life,&quot; Boehner had said at Stanford University.</p><p>Cruz, the leading Senate proponent of stripping the Affordable Care Act of funding, played a key role in pushing for the 2013 government shutdown — a move Boehner said led to perhaps the &quot;dumbest&quot; situation he's ever witnessed.</p><p>He also took a swipe at the House Freedom Caucus, whose conservative members led the effort to drive him from office:</p><blockquote class="twitter-tweet" data-lang="en"><p lang="en" dir="ltr">At <a href="https://twitter.com/salt2016">@SALT2016</a>, <a href="https://twitter.com/SpeakerBoehner">@SpeakerBoehner</a> calls House Freedom Caucus &quot;knuckleheads ... to this day I don't know what they want.&quot; <a href="https://t.co/oXZw0xWQ9w">pic.twitter.com/oXZw0xWQ9w</a></p><p>— Rick Newman (@rickjnewman) <a href="https://twitter.com/rickjnewman/status/730781584706523137">May 12, 2016</a></p></blockquote><p><br /></p><script async="" src="//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script><p>The caucus later responded on its official Twitter account:</p><blockquote class="twitter-tweet" data-lang="en"><p lang="en" dir="ltr">.<a href="https://twitter.com/johnboehner">@johnboehner</a> We want GOP to actually be party of ltd gov't, less spending; hold WH accountable for exec overreach. <a href="https://t.co/KPzwZKOZGK">https://t.co/KPzwZKOZGK</a></p><p>— House Freedom Caucus (@freedomcaucus) <a href="https://twitter.com/freedomcaucus/status/730792160308674565">May 12, 2016</a></p></blockquote><p><br /></p><script async="" src="//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script><p>Overall, Boehner seemed pretty pleased to have left Congress. “Every day when I read the news I’m reminded of how happy I am that I’m not in the chaos,” he said.</p><br><br></content:encoded>

      <title>Huckabee rips Romney's attack on Trump</title>
      <link>http://www.politico.com/story/2016/05/mike-huckabee-slams-mitt-romney-223123</link>
      <description/>
      <content:encoded><p>Former presidential rival Mike Huckabee laced into Mitt Romney on Thursday, a day after the Republican Party's 2012 nominee resurfaced his criticism of Donald Trump's refusal to release his tax returns.</p><p>&quot;I supported Romney, just as I will Trump, despite having serious differences with both. I believe that if you’re a Republican, then you respect the voters’ choice,&quot; the former Arkansas governor wrote in a post on his website titled &quot;Romney’s motto 'Do unto Others as has been done unto me.'&quot;</p><p>&quot;But I am especially disappointed in Mitt for this latest attack,&quot; Huckabee continued. &quot;He’s not only trying to sink his own party’s presumptive nominee, but he’s factually incorrect and he’s making the same unfair attack on Trump that was launched against him in 2012.&quot;</p><p>Romney alluded to his initial refusal to release his tax returns in a <a href="http://www.politico.com/story/2016/05/mitt-romney-donald-trump-tax-returns-223088" target="_blank">Facebook post </a>Wednesday that otherwise excoriated the party's presumptive nominee's withholding of the documents as &quot;disqualifying.&quot; </p><p>&quot;Anticipating inquiries regarding my own tax release history, I released my 2010 tax returns in January of 2012 and I released my 2011 tax returns as soon as they were completed, in September of 2012,&quot; Romney wrote.</p><p>Huckabee wrote that he has &quot;long argued&quot; that candidates should resist calls to release their personal tax forms. If Trump does not release his tax returns by Election Day, he will be the first candidate to forgo the practice since President Gerald Ford released a summary in 1976.</p><p>Besides, Huckabee added, the average voter stands to learn little about Trump from the documents but they could be a &quot;treasure trove for opponents to lift items out of context to make him look shady.&quot;</p><p>&quot;Early in my political career, I volunteered to release all my tax returns. Why not? I had nothing to hide. If anything, I was probably too honest and paid too much tax. It sure felt like it! But I learned that honesty and good intentions don’t count for squat in politics,&quot; Huckabee wrote. &quot;My opponents still twisted things out of context to try to make me look like a tax cheat. You can do that to anyone because nobody understands the tax code, not even the IRS agents in charge of enforcing it.&quot; </p><p>&quot;If Mitt Romney wants to talk about taxes while showing the world what a real Republican stands for, he should stop trying to destroy the party’s presumptive nominee and instead aim his fire at a more appropriate target: the 70,000-plus-page tax code,&quot; Huckabee concluded.</p><br></content:encoded>

      <title>Trump accuses Bezos of using the Washington Post to avoid taxes</title>
      <link>http://www.politico.com/story/2016/05/donald-trump-jeff-bezos-washington-post-223148</link>
      <description/>
      <content:encoded><p>Donald Trump is done with Jeff Bezos. </p><p>In an interview with Fox News’ Sean Hannity on Thursday night, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee alleged that the Amazon founder uses the Washington Post to secure tax benefits for his company.</p><p>“Every hour we’re getting calls from reporters from The Washington Post asking ridiculous questions and I will tell you, this is owned as a toy by Jeff Bezos, who controls Amazon,” Trump said in response to Hannity's question about how the paper has assigned some 20 reporters to dig deep into his life.</p><p>Amazon is “getting away with murder, tax-wise,” said Trump. “He’s using the Washington Post for power so that the politicians in Washington don’t tax Amazon like they should be taxed.&quot;</p><p>Bezos, who purchased the Post in 2013 for $250 million, has a broader “antitrust” problem, Trump alleged.</p><p>“Amazon is controlling so much of what they’re doing,” he said. “And what they’ve done is he bought this paper for practically nothing and he’s using that as a tool for political power against me and against people and I’ll tell you what, we can’t let him get away with it.” </p><p>Trump went on to criticize the Post's reporters, who he claimed have reported inaccurately on his life.</p><p>“I just heard, they’re taking these really bad stories, I mean they’re wrong, I wouldn’t even say bad, they’re wrong and in many cases they have no proper information,&quot; he said.</p> <br><p>“He’s using The Washington Post, which is peanuts, he’s using that for political purposes to save Amazon in terms of taxes and in terms of antitrust,” Trump reiterated.</p><p>Bezos has long said he purchased the paper because he thought he might be able to save an important journalistic institution.</p><p>“I didn’t know anything about the newspaper business, but I did know something about the Internet,” Bezos <a href="http://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/12/02/amazons-bezos-explains-why-he-bought-the-washington-post/" target="_blank">said</a> at a conference in 2014. “That, combined with the financial runway that I can provide, is the reason why I bought The Post.”</p><p>Earlier in the week, <a href="http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/woodward-20-wapo-reporters-dig-dirt-on-trump-every-phase-of-his-life/article/2591021" target="_blank">the Washington Examiner</a> reported on comments the Post’s Bob Woodward made at a realtor trade association conference in the city.  </p><p>&quot;There's a lot we don't know,&quot; he said, according to the Examiner. &quot;We have 20 people working on Trump, we're going to do a book, we're doing articles about every phase of his life.”</p><br><p>Woodward also said the Bezos had urged the paper to report thoroughly on the presidential candidates, according to the Examiner.</p><p>&quot;He said, 'Look the job at the Washington Post has to be tell us everything about who the eventual nominee will be in both parties, 15-part, 16-part series, 20-part series. We want to look at every part of their lives and we're never going get the whole story of course but we can get the best attainable,” Woodward said.</p><p>Earlier in the day today, Executive Editor Martin Baron addressed the question this way: </p><p>“As the individual who oversees The Washington Post’s news staff, I can say categorically that I have received no instructions from Jeff Bezos regarding our coverage of the presidential campaign — or, for that matter, any other subject. The Post has a long tradition of publishing thorough examinations of the major party nominees for president. The decision to write a book on Donald Trump came entirely from the newsroom.”</p><p><i>Hadas Gold contributed.</i></p><br></content:encoded>
